description:
Aspergillus melleus is a species of filamentous fungus that belongs to the genus Aspergillus. It is commonly found in soil, decaying organic matter, and various types of food and agricultural products.

Aspergillus melleus is characterized by its production of yellow to brownish-yellow colored colonies when grown on laboratory media. The fungus produces septate hyphae, which are branched and form a dense, felt-like mycelium. The conidiophores (reproductive structures) of A. melleus are typically short and bear globose vesicles, which in turn produce chains of smooth-walled conidia (spores).

Taxonomically, Aspergillus melleus is classified under the subgenus Fumigati and the section Fumigati. This species is known to produce various secondary metabolites, including the mycotoxin ochratoxin A, which can potentially pose a health risk to humans and animals if present in contaminated food or feed.

Aspergillus melleus is considered a saprophytic fungus, meaning it plays a role in the decomposition of organic matter in natural environments. However, it can also be an opportunistic pathogen, potentially causing infections in immunocompromised individuals, such as those with certain medical conditions or undergoing cancer treatment.
